Posts.Content: Hi all - this afternoon I had my 15th and final session of radiotherapy!  I had a few tears in the car on the way home - think it was just the relief of having come so far.  I remember looking at the first draft of my treatment plan drawn up by the oncologist and thinking "I can't do it" well ...  I DID!  7 sessions of chemotherapy, a lumpectomy, sentinel node biopsy, 2nd surgery plus axillary node dissection, 15 sessions of radiotherapy, 9 Herceptin injections (9 still to go), daily Letrazole .... and a partridge in a pear tree!  Come on ladies you can do it too. I have entered Race For Life in June with my two daughters in support as I feel I want to give something back.  Love and hugs to all xxx
Posts.Title: Last radiotherapy session done and ticked off - yay!

Posts.Content: I have been on daily Letrazole for 14 months and still get achy joints particularly when I first get up in the morning and from being seated. It's difficult to get down the stairs first thing in the morning - I feel about 90! Once I'm up and about I'm fine and can walk miles with my dog with no problem.  I go swimming now and again which feels really good for joints and muscles. Denise
Posts.Title: Pain in joints and muscles

Posts.Content: Hi all after my emotional meltdown and rambling post last on Saturday evening, after a long dog walk yesterday morning, albeit still crying, I felt much better. I cleared out the loft and spare bedroom in the afternoon which took hours but I felt good girl doing.  Thanks for all your posts of support. We have a huge amount of emotional and psychological fallout to deal with after cancer treatment. When moaning to my daughter about my husband's insensitivity, she reminded me that he has been by my side throughout and has had heart problems to deal with himself which made me feel selfish. On a lighter note we kept the little dog. My husband finally recognised my fragile emotional state and didn't think I would cope well with parting with her as I've become very attached to her.  He phoned the lady who was coming to see her and she was very understanding. In conversation it turned out she had treatment for breast cancer herself 20 years ago.  I feel happy we have kept her as she has settled so well and both fogs slept all night yay!  Denise xx.
Posts.Title: Thank you all for your support ... feeling back on track

Posts.Content: Amazing and just the positive boost I needed today as had a bit of a low this afternoon. Well done - a fantastic achievement.
Posts.Title: 10k Great Scottish Run

Posts.Content: Happy Birthday Ali - have a great day.  Enjoying sharing your pics of my favourite actor. Denise xx
Posts.Title: HAPPY BIRTHDAY

Posts.Content: Happy Birthday Ali - have a great day.  Enjoying sharing your pics of my favourite actor. Denise xx
Posts.Title: HAPPY BIRTHDAY

Posts.Content: Hi Claire this is really bad as you have enough anxiety to deal with a this time. I was fairly fortunate with my appointments being sent through but I did have to chase a couple.  One was for an ultrasound scan which without the results of would have made my next meeting with the oncologist pointless.  It was when my appointments didn't ycome through on time that I became anxious - almost like I felt I had been forgotten!  I mentioned it to the oncologist at my next appointment and it didn't happen again.  I know it's just a slip up on the Admin side but when you are going through what we are its hugely important. Having them in place gave me a sense of reassurance.  Like Ani I did at one point feel I needed to keep a check on them and even created a spreadsheet to log and keep a record of my appointments - 53 to date!  It might seem a bit over the top for some but made me feel more in control - I needed to doit for my employer anyway.  Appointments come through like clockwork now - I even got the same one twice for my next heart scan but better that way! Hope all starts going to plan for Julie - make sure you speak up! Sending hugs. Denise xx
Posts.Title: treatment plan appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: Hi - I haven't been on here in a while but can't sleep tonight. I'm 3 years post diagnosis and in November last year also had a lymph node come up in my neck. My GP referred me for an ultrasound and, due to my history, I was then referred back to my oncologist. By the time I saw him the node had disappeared and was put down to the fact I had a cold prior to it appearing so it was just a normal reaction to a virus. Try not to worry ... difficult I know as I was in tears when I was referred back but it all turned out fine.
Posts.Title: Swollen lymph node in neck

Posts.Content: Hi Helen my big toe nails were bruised ... one of them actually lifted off!  I thought I had kicked something but realise it was to do with side effects of chemo. Denise xx
Posts.Title: Bruised Toe Nails

Posts.Content: Hi ladies great day today when my two daughters and I took part in the local Race For Life event.  I jogged it and completed the 5k in 48 minutes - not bad for a first attempt!  It was a great atmosphere and we ar definitely doing it again next year.  Home for a BBQ in the sunshine after ... fantastic!  Just about gor enough energy left to take the dog for a walk then I will be done!
Posts.Title: Race for Life done and dusted ....

Posts.Content: We all know cancer seems to be everywhere we turn via the media - documentaries, adverts, magazines, novels and films. Having just heard the new song "I Wasn't Expecting a That" by Jamie Lawson so now it's in song lyrics too!  I understand there is a need for awareness - we have just had a Macmillan Coffee Morning at work and are holding a "Wear It Pink" day next week but there seems to be no escape!  It just brings me down and I think some people are almost exploiting it to sell books, CDs etc! Moan over.  On the positive side, I saw my oncologist yesterday for a follow up appointment having completed my 18 Herceptin injections two weeks ago.  All is good and she is amazed how well I have come through  the treatment.  Happy, happy! Also after fracturing my fifth metatarsal five  weeks ago, I am now boot free.  It wasn't related to bone density ... just my attempt to be glam and wear wedge sandals!  Back in sensible flatties now. Hope all you ladies are doing ok too.  Have  good weekend.   Denise xx
Posts.Title: It's even getting into songs now ....

Posts.Content: I can totally empathise.  I am a year post treatment and have regularly hit meltdowns both in mood and emotions but these do seem to be getting less.  I do have periods of black patches where things seem pointless but then I pick up again.   The medication can cause depression but I don't want anti depressives. The other day I actually felt sorry for the soft monkey toy that was strapped to the rear bumper of a truck!! Then my husband and I went to a 60s New Amen Corner event which was great with all the songs off yesteryear but I found myself welling up!  I get tearful when I'm happy or sad. It's my birthday on Saturday and I'm going to a wedding fayre with my daughter on Sunday as she is wedding planning so I will probably be a soggy wreck.  I think our hormones have been shot to pieces along with everything else.  Sadly another of the side effects of bring a survivor. xx
Posts.Title: Over Emotional....

Posts.Content: Hi Julia thanks for your lovely response which gave me a boost.  I did get upset when the Consultant said he was referring me back to hospital but he did say if it wasn't for my cancer history he probably wouldn't have which was slightly reassuring.  It did start after three weeks of having a bad cold which seems a coincidence. Must start checking in again as it's so nice to chat to you ladies.  I went with my 23 year old daughter to see a local production of Annie this evening as she has always loved it.  A great evening and lovely memories. xx
Posts.Title: Painful neck after bad cold ....

Posts.Content: Hello everyone - I haven't posted in here in a while but am seeking a little advice/shared experiences.  A few weeks ago I was laid low by a bad cough/cold which left me with a muzzy head.  I also noticed my neck was quite painful like when you turn quickly and crick it.  Ralgex and anti inflammatory gels ease it but I thought I would mention it at a follow up for my blood pressure monitor.  My own GP - who I have had a catalogue of issues with pre and since diagnosis - was quite dismissive.  He got me to open my mouth and felt my neck then with a cursory "well there are a couple of nodes slightly raised" and prescribed diazepan as a relaxant. When I saw another GP last Friday for another issue, I mentioned it to her. She could see I was anxious and ordered a full blood test which I had yesterday and an ultrasound which I had today.  The Consultant said there were a couple of nodes behind my ear which were slightly enlarged.  In fairness he did say if it wasn't for my breast cancer history he would not have referred me further as they could be "reactive nodes" which have come up in defence of infection such as the cold.  However, you can imagine how anxious I am at being referred back to the hospital to check all is well.  He did say they may have gone down by the time I have my hospital appointment in which case they will take no further action ... if not it will be a needle aspiration.  Anybody else had any similar experiences?  Positive vibes needed please ladies.  Living with constant anxiety is so difficult.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Painful neck after bad cold ....

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for your reply.  The Consultant said if it wasn't for my cancer history he wouldn't have referred me but it's just to be on the safe side.  I did have a cold for three weeks solid prior to the neck pain which is a coincidence.  He said that by the time I get to my hospital appointment they may have gone down so nothing will need to be done.  Let's hope and pray that happens. xx
Posts.Title: Painful neck after bad cold ....

Posts.Content: Hi JJsailor I had exactly the same worry and couldn't wait to see my Breast Consultant yesterday for my follow up appointment.  I had my surgery last December followed by 15 sessions of radiotherapy which finished in March.The Breast Consultant didn't seem concerned and was almost sure the firmness I could feel was scar tissue and also the result of radiotherapy.  I am, however, due for a mammogram as its a year since I was diagnosed so he said he would book that to reassure me.  I think it's just that we are ultra aware of our bodies now and on high alert which isn't a bad thing.  It might be worth you getting checked if you can't wait until your post op appointment just to put your mind at rest but I feel sure you will be told it's the tissue healing after surgery. Denise xx
Posts.Title: Does anyone else feel a new lump after breast lump removal?

Posts.Content: So happy to report my appointment with my oncologist went well.  I was referred after an ultrasound on a painful neck showed a couple of enlarged nodes on the side of my naughty boob.  Thankfully all is well and it was considered they were probably just reactive to infection. If they had still been raised I would have had to have a biopsy which I was dreading plus the agonising wait leading up to Christmas! Also,my new oncologist is a lovely man who really listened. My original oncologist was so amazing I didn't feel anyone could replace her so I am relieved on all counts.  I am not from USA but have a lot to be thankful for today!
Posts.Title: Oncology appointment ... so grateful for the reassurance I needed

Posts.Content: Hi Genny it sounds like your diagnosis was the same as mine - stage 2 with one lymph node involved.  I finished my radiotherapy in March and am now on Herceptin injections every three weeks - 12 down, 6 to go and daily Letrazole.  I have been back to my part time job since end of January and enjoy the distraction it provides.  Most days are fine but I do have times of anxiety and low mood although these are becoming less often.  I agree the whole experience messes with your head as much as your body.  People expect you to pick up your life where you left off almost like "well that's that done" but it's not that easy.  I wen to see my GP following an emotional meltdown the other weekend which happens to coincide with the tragic news of Rio Ferdinand's wife dying and the C Word being on TV - which I didn't watch! I actually saw a young Registrar at my appointment as I refuse to see my own GP who I feel seriously failed me - but that's another story. He listened and suggested Mindfullness sessions which I have booked on to, ensuring I get "healthy sleep" and setting myself goals with things I enjoy such as my craft hobbies.  I did buy apiano when I was first diagnosed - a knee jerk reaction as I have always wanted to play.  I have self taught myself so far but do intend having lessons.  I am also having acupuncture through the local cancer support unit to help with joint ache from Letrazole.  As I said to Susie I think it's a case of adjusting to the new normal both physically band mentally.  The bottom line for me is that Iam still here!  Keep on keeping on and keep posting - would be interested to compare notes.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with breast cancer Nov 14'. Lumpectomy no spread in lymph...

Posts.Content: It's not often I get days like this but today I feel really down.  My daughter and her fiancé are coming over later but although I've been awake since 7am I am struggling to get out of bed.  I seem to have been sideswiped by low mood.  For the past couple of weeks the aches in my shoulders, pins and needles and cramps in my hands on waking have been getting worse and I have convinced myself something is not right.  I finished chemo at the end of November last year and am now on Herceptin injections and Letrazole.  I tried ringing my BCN weeks ago and left a message.  She phoned back 10 days later but by then I felt a little easier.  I tried to make an appointment with my oncologist last week but the earliest I could get was 29th May with the Registrar.  As I have my first oncologist check up post clearance on 11th June anyway I decided to wait till then.  Do you think my GP could help?  I just need reassurance that symptoms are side effects of treatment and nothing more.  What hasn't helped was a comment someone at a retirement party made to me recently that her friend had been given the all clear then it came back in her spine and three months later she died!  Think this is playing on my mind.  Sorry to be a moaner. Denise xx
Posts.Title: Feeling down today ....

Posts.Content: Well ladies the rhubarb crumble albeit traditional style was yummy!  I made lovely custard to go with it.  I had a good cry when my eldest daughter arrived earlier and feel better for it.  Onwards and upwards - tomorrow is another day ... but I am going to get a GP appointment on Tuesday to check out a few things.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Feeling down today ....

Posts.Content: Hi Pinkshoe I can totally empathise with how you are feeling.  I was diagnosed in May 2014 - had chemo, lumpectomy, radiotherapy, Herceptin injections and now on Letrazole.  I had a clear mammogram last June and saw my Breast Consultant in December who confirmed by letter there was no evidence of recurrence.  I ache so much in different places all the time and am constantly analysing every twinge.  I recently saw my GP Who sent me for a blood test and have now been asked to make a non urgent routine appointment as it was "borderline".  I am now anxious again!  I think we have been through such a traumatic experience of diagnosis and treatment that we will always be hyper aware of how we are feeling.  I am always grateful to still be here but there are some huge things we have to deal with emotionally and physically.  Stay strong and positive.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Everything spells cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Karen - thanks for the link.  I had read the Cancer Research link prior to my ops but just wondered how they determined the number of nodes they take as this seems to vary.  Dreamthief - I had 3 nodes taken during sentinel node biopsy with one node bring affected.  I then had 7 nodes taken during second op which were all clear.  Learning things all the time albeit on a subject I never wanted to!  Thanks all.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Lymph Nodes - Question for Dreamthief

Posts.Content: Thanks to all you lovely ladies for your replies.  I did manage to get up and made a rhubarb crumble and a banana and rhubarb smoothie!  I got 2 packs of rhubarb at the reduced bargain price of 10p last night!  We are cooking a pork joint in a pulled pork sauce in the slow cooker and I have made some garlic and herb wedges to go with it.  I feel better for doing something.  My youngest daughter came home from her boyfriend's this morning.  She usually works Sunday's but has a day off so it's lovely having her home.  She came and had a good chat with me while I was still in bed.  AliG58 - yes I usually enjoy some time to myself but Cancer has even taken that away from me.  It was reassuring to hear someone else is suffering with peripheral neuropathy - I am sure it is the Herceptin that's to blame although I did start to get a little of it after my last dose of Docetaxel. Good luck with getting a dog Judith - my little Westie has become so close to me since diagnosis. If I have a nap in the afternoon she is always there with me and, of course, encourages me to get out for walks.  We also had an older Westie but sadly had to say goodbye to him last year just after my diagnosis!  I have almost persuaded my husband to get a rescue dog when we return from holiday in July.  I think it's good to have things to focus on.  We have just had half of our lawn (which was in poor condition) dug up and my husband has made a vegetable plot - mind you the amount we have paid out so far on this project, these cauliflowers will be costing me £30 ha ha! It was very sad to hear about Rio Ferdinand's wife yesterday - just what I didn't need to hear at the moment but makes me realise I am fortunate to have been given a chance however tough it can be! Love chatting to you lovely ladies - sending good wishes to you all.  Denise xxx
Posts.Title: Feeling down today ....

Posts.Content: Hi susieq123 I was going through exactly what you are and still do.  Some days I feel relatively normal then suddenly I am sideswiped by a down mood and anxiety sets it.  This hit me worst when I had completed my treatment but after researching it now know this is completely normal.  I had an emotional meltdown a couple of weekends ago and was even going to pay privately for a scan.  However, as my husband said how long would it be before the reassurance from this wore off and the anxiety would kick in again?  I did attend an 8 week Cancer Survivorship Programme through my local cancer support unit.  This taught strategies and techniques for coping post cancer as well as nutritional advice.  I have also had some complementary therapies including massage and acupuncture and have booked onto a Mindfullness course.   Although the treatment we receive in the UK is excellent, I think we lag behind in addressing the emotional and mental impact of cancer. I bought a couple of books off Amazon relating survivorship stories as I gain strength and inspiration from these.  They were both published in USA - both USA and Canada appear to be way ahead in supporting cancer survivors.  I do think we will reach a point in our recovery where we wake up and cancer is not the first thing on our mind ... it just takes time to adjust mentally. I have my six month post surgery appointment with my Breast Consultant on Monday and plan to ask lots of questions.   Keep going ... you will get a bit stronger every day and always know there are others who know how you feel.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with breast cancer Nov 14'. Lumpectomy no spread in lymph...

Posts.Content: In the main I am managing to get on with life despite aching constantly, feeling tired and still not feeling "normal".  However periodically I hit meltdowns in mood and it is during these times I obsess about recurrence.  Everything I seem to read or hear about then seems to be another case of the dreaded C returning. I find myself anlysing every ache or pain.  My husband doesn't understand - to him the cancer is history and doesn't appreciate the emotional and mental impact it has had on me. He actually said I am almost waiting for it to come back just so I can say "I told you so"!
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Hi Dreamthief - just out of interest do you know what determines how many lymph nodes they take during sentinel node biopsy or axillary node clearance?  Some people seem to have 20+ but others have only a few. I know you are a fount of knowledge for which we are all very grateful. Thanks.  Denise
Posts.Title: Lymph Nodes - Question for Dreamthief

Posts.Content: Thanks mistymoley - I was just curious.  This time last year I knew nothing about breast cancer but now know quite a lot.  This was just something I hadn't read or heard about.  You are a great source of information - much appreciated.  Denise x
Posts.Title: Lymph Nodes - Question for Dreamthief

Posts.Content: Hi I had four sessions of EC chemo which went relatively smoothly apart from hair loss, slight nausea and sleep disturbance. I have my first session of three of Docetaxel on Friday and am a little apprehensive of side effects but will just take it as it comes - can't stop half way through! I also have my first Herceptin injection on 30th September and will have to continue with these every three weeks for a year. It's a long journey but good to know others are going through it with you. Stay strong ... we can do this! xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxil experiences

Posts.Content: Hi Jen I can totally identify with your post.  I completed treatment last September but still have meltdowns now and again.   I had one such meltdown in November when I found out my friend's dad had been diagnosed with terminal lung cancer and given three months - he passed away last Monday. She is getting married in March so has been on an emotional roller coaster.  She was glad she managed to put her wedding dress on so her dad could see her in it which brought tears to my eyes.  Anyway her news and the sadness in her face when she told me came back to me later that evening and I just couldn't stop crying.  My usually supportive husband told me to "stop wallowing" as "you don't have cancer any more".  He also implied the family were tired of me wanting to talk about cancer although my daughters have since reassured me this isn't the case.  I know the whole experience puts relationships under great strain particularly after the shock of the original diagnosis and before you know your treatment plan/prognosis.  Having said that I don't think there is enough consideration given to the massive emotional/physical impact that hits like a train once treatment ends.  People expect you to just pick up where you left off but it's not that easy. I've been referred for counselling through our local cancer support unit which I am looking forward to having.  Most of the time I cope but the anxiety/depression creeps in without warning and can be tough. Take care. Denise x
Posts.Title: Husband remark to cancer

Posts.Content: Yay another good news story!  Fantastic to hear this - really inspires those going through it or those working their way to the next scan.  May your good health long continue! Denise xx
Posts.Title: Picking up the pieces

Posts.Content: Hi Gaynor after my first dose of EC I can remember sitting at home in the evening waiting for the side effects to kick in! I was even worried about taking a bath in case something started happening!  I was amazed that I was able to walk the dog the same day and just felt slightly nauseous which the Domperidone took care of.  I was mostly able to carry on as normal during all my chemo including working when it wasn't my low white cell phase.  Just take things as they come, eat when you want to, rest when you need to. Hopefully you will get off as lightly as I did.  They have to warn you about all the possible side effects but it doesn't mean you will get them and there is help if yo do.  Look after yourself.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: First chemo treatment yesterday

Posts.Content: Hi DH77 sorry you have had to join our Group but you can be reassured of support here from people who understand what you are going through.  I was diagnosed at the end of May 2014 and had 4 x FEC chemo followed by 4 Docetaxel.  You will be told about all the possible side effects at your pre chemo assessment but always remember it doesn't mean you will get them.  Everyone is different so just take things one step at a time.  If you do get side effects there are things that can help you.  I was very fortunate and had minimal side effects apart from hair loss and slight nausea so was able to continue working in between chemo sessions and carry on as normal.  My children are grown up so I did not have that concern but I have met mums since diagnosis who have gone through treatment while looking after young children.  It will be useful to have support on days you may feel more tired than unusual but again everyone is different with this.  You will also need to avoid infection around days 7-10 of chemo when white blood count can be reduced but I work in an office in a nursery and managed to miss picking up anything.  It's just a case of being more aware.  George and Jackie, the moderators of this site, can recommend items to get you through chemo.  Look after yourself, eat what you like when you feel like it and rest when you need to.  You will be guided through your treatment by you oncology team.  One step at a time, cross bridges as you get to them.  You can do it.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and child care

Posts.Content: Hi they have lots of the Adult Colouring Books in The Works and WH Smiths as they are now widely recognised as stress therapy.  I have many and find them really relaxing.  I would also recommend yoga, chillout music, mindfulness books / attending mindfulness sessions.  Do you have a local cancer support unit? We have The Olive Tree which is attached to our hospital and is fantastic in the support it delivers including stress relief, mindfulness and yoga. It's worth exploring different options to find one that suits you.  I have completed treatment but still hit low patches when I need to find something to boost my mood.  Be kind to yourself and rest when you need to.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Fear & Low Moods

Posts.Content: Hi AliG58 - I have had all my Herceptin by sub cut - 10th one coming up next Tuesday and by the sounds of it definitely the best way to go.  Great that you are finding this way easier.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Sub-cut herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies - a positive post but interested to hear of any other similar experiences.  While on chemotherapy I was warned that one possible side effect is nails darkening, splitting and even lifting off.  As a precaution I started applying Rimmel  Salon Pro Kate Moss polish.  I have never been able to grow my nails to any length without them flaking or breaking off.  Well I am amazed that I have nail growth like never before ... they have never been so strong and are so even look like acrylics! I'm not sure what the reason is but it is a small positive.  I am on daily Letrazole and having Herceptin injections every three weeks so don't know if it is to do with this.  I hope whatever it is has the same effect on my hair growth.  On that note, my hair is slowly growing back but, as I anticipated, is 50 shades of grey! Denise xx
Posts.Title: Nail growth ...

Posts.Content: Great Helen - we had an Italia weekend in our town in April.  It was lovely - just needed the sunshine and scenery ... Thanks for your good wishes Sister Snail - I am doing ok and hope you are too. xx
Posts.Title: Just saying hello ....

Posts.Content: Hi Ali Owl we went to Sorrento today for a visit.  We are staying near to Amalfi and have also visited Ravello and Positano since we arrived last Friday.  We are hoping to visit Capri before we leave.  Yes we were on the same treatment path at the same time.  Hope you are keeping well. Denise xx
Posts.Title: Just saying hello ....

Posts.Content: Thanks Dawn. I think as with the EC chemo they have to tell you all the side effects but it doesn't mean you are going to get them. I think we just have to plough on and take it as it comes ... we don't have a lot of choice in this. Anyway, I hope we can compare notes and support each other .... we are in this together and will come through. I promise not to scare you whatever - I am not a quitter and despite a few down days remain strong and positive. This is just an inconvenient phase in our lives - something none of us saw coming. Stay strong. Denise x
Posts.Title: About to start Docetaxel ... feeling nervous

Posts.Content: Hi I am new to the site. I was diagnosed with breast cancer at the end of May. The feelings of devastation following the initial diagnosis and anxiety waiting for a biopsy and the result were extremely hard to deal with. Your mind takes you to all weird and wonderful places! Once my treatment plan was in place I felt more in control. I am having neo adjuvant chemo prior to a lumpectomy. I have just had my 4th session of EC chemo and will start my first session of Docetaxel followed by my first Herceptin end Sept. Apart from hair loss, nausea and sleep disturbance I have been fairly ok so consider myself fortunate. I am very apprehensive about the side effects of the Docetaxel and any reactions on the first session. I know I will need to just go with it and manage side effects as they present. Surgery will follow and possibly radiotherapy. It's a long journey with good days, bad days emotionally - bit of a roller coaster but overall keeping strong and positive. I would like to hear from anyone who has had the same treatment plan. Sorry about my user name - tried loads more before this but they had been taken so in desperation ha ha. Look forward to chatting later - off to work today. Denise
Posts.Title: About to start Docetaxel ... feeling nervous

Posts.Content: Haven't been on in a while but just to let you know I'm enjoying a few days away on the Amalfi Coast with my husband.  It's so beautiful here my cancer experience seems to be unreal and have been a lifetime ago.  Oncologist routine check up in 11 days time but not thinking too much about it.  Try to make the best of every day ... it certainly helps cope with the bad ones. Sending hugs to you all to keep positive. Denise xx
Posts.Title: Just saying hello ....

Posts.Content: Hi Amber welcome to this site - it's somewhere none of us wanted to be but the support here is fantastic.  There are ladies who are going through or have been through what you are so they fully understand and can give advice or share experiences.  I was absolutely devastated to receive my diagnosis in May 2014, the day after my daughter's 21st birthday celebrations.  I was numb and in denial for a good while but once my treatment plan was in place and things started moving I felt more positive.  I went through chemo, 2 surgeries and radiotherapy and have just had the all clear from my first mammogram post treatment.  My best advice to you is to take one step at a time and cross bridges as you get to them.  Looking too far ahead can be overwhelming.  Just know treatment for breast cancer these days is excellent and improving all the time.  Once you find out details of your diagnosis you will be given details of the treatment options for you.  Come back and let us know as I am sure there will be plenty of ladies here who will have had the same diagnosis and who will be able to offer support.  George and Jackie, the site moderators have loads of knowledge to pass on.  I know it's easy for me to say but try to stay calm ... waiting for results at the beginning is probably the most difficult time.  Sending you hugs ((xx)). Denise
Posts.Title: Dreading results

Posts.Content: Hi Amber I'm pleased you are feeling more positive.  I was also Stage 2 with one lymph node out of 10 affected but I'm HER2 Positive.  I was also unsure about making plans for the future at the outset ... I now look back and see how many of my fears were unfounded.  It felt like a bomb had exploded in my little world when I was given the diagnosis and I remember walking out of the Consultant's office thinking "Well that's it then .... game over."  I was supposed to be meeting friends for lunch the next day but phoned on the way home from hospital to cancel as I felt like I had been shot onto a parallel universe!  Hey, 14 months after diagnosis and I am still here and just had my first clear mammogram.  I like the bit about the salesman ... the same has worked for me a few times.  I stopped wearing my contact lenses when I was diagnosed ... don't know why as I had worn them for over 30 years but it was an extra thing I didn't want to bother with.  I went to Specsavers to update my glasses and they tried all the usual buy one get one half price tactics plus all add ons.  I explained I wanted a straight forward pair of glasses as I was going through breast cancer treatment ... all sorted within 10 minutes £50.  Also when I went in last week for some prescription sunglasses they just charged me for the frames.  I think when I said I didn't want to pay too much for a pair as didn't know how much I would use them she thought I meant I was on my way out but I meant because of the unpredictable weather in this country!  Take strength from all the positives no matter how small and focus on getting through this.  I have a great cancer support unit The Olive Tree attached to the hospital.  They have been amazing with anything from wigs to therapy sessions to drop in support.  Denise x
Posts.Title: Dreading results

Posts.Content: Hi Susie my hair grew back 50 shades of grey and curly!  I tried to convince myself I should leave it natural but just couldn't get used to being totally grey and almost white in places just yet!  I finished chemo last November and, reluctant to use chemicals, bought a Daniel Field natural dye.  However, I had heard that unless you have chemicals on your hair first, this would not take on the brand new hair.   I went to a Hayley, a young hairdresser in our local town who had lymphoma herself and went through chemo as I knew she had knowledge of hair after cancer treatment.  She is amazing and has opened a wig consultancy at the back of her salon as she found it difficult to find wigs locally.  She was more concerned about how long it had been since my hair started growing back - mine was 8 months.  I left it to her and she coloured and highlighted it - I just have to straighten it although the curls have given it body!  Although my wig served me well it was nice to be able to go without it especially in the hot weather - strange how it took a while to get used to going without it though!  Denise xx
Posts.Title: When can I colour my hair after chemo and do I need to use a vegetable...

Posts.Content: Hi ladies whilst my wig has served me very well, my own hair, albeit 50 shades of grey, had grown so much I was finding it increasingly difficult to keep under my wig!  I did struggle with the idea of leaving it natural but just couldn't get used to being grey and curly!  Today I went along to the salon - the hairdresser Hayley had Hodgkins Lymphoma two years ago and had treatment so was very understanding.  She has opened a wig consultation service at the back of her salon as she struggled to find a wig locally when she needed one.  Hayley was quite shocked to see how grey my hair was but I left it to her to fix it. It's going to take a while to get used to and the fringe is still far too short but will grow!   It's going to be strange not wearing my wig but it was also quite emotional getting the real me back.  One more thing ticked off.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Took the plunge and went to hairdressers today ...

Posts.Content: Hi Diane yes they do as well as Sainsburys, Tescos and The Works as they are now widely recognised as stress therapy.  I have many and find them really relaxing.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Adult colouring books

Posts.Content: Hi Highland Mum - I waited almost three weeks after my mammogram before being brave enough to ring for the results which were fine.  Each day that passed with no letter or call I took to be a good sign based on "no news is good news".   I don't think they send out results routinely but am sure we would hear pretty quickly if there was anything of concern.  Denise x
Posts.Title: mammogram results?

Posts.Content: Hi lovely ladies - thanks for all your kind comments.  It felt strange going to work this morning but good - not so keen on having to allow time to straighten and mess with it first thing though!  Monika I uploaded the photo from my iPad - just click on the photo icon then find the photo you want to upload.  Claire - my hair started growing back last October - find and slow to start but quite quickly once it got going.  It was really grey and curly and almost white in parts or 50 shades of grey as I called it!  I just couldn't get used to it so decided to have a colour put on it.  Crystaljuju - the Avatar photo is me wearing my wig! I was very fortunate as I got it from the Cancer Support Unit who have been fab.  Although I have a couple this one served me well throughout and many people didn't realise it was a wig ... I even fooled the nurses on the chemo ward who thought I had used the cold cap and kept my hair!  I am going to keep it just for back up on days I don't fancy messing with my own hair ha ha!  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Took the plunge and went to hairdressers today ...

Posts.Content: Hi Jediknight I totally agree with you.  Who would want to go and watch such a film as entertainment? I get fed up of everything I read, everything I watch being about cancer especially when the outcome isn't good.  Reality is one thing but having to read/watch it as fiction is too much.  I went with my family for dinner and to the cinema to see "Blended" just after I was diagnosed.  It was supposed to be a pick me up treat but although the film was a light hearted comedy, Adam Sandler's wife had died from cancer .... lowered the mood somewhat - you just can't get away from it! Denise xx
Posts.Title: Miss you already

Posts.Content: Another clear mammogram result ... feels like I'm flying without wings! I only had it done 6 days ago and was told not ring for results before three weeks but the Breast Care Nurse called me about something else and was able to see the result. Diagnosed May 2014, NED since Jan 2015 ... rocking on.
Posts.Title: Whoop whoop ... mammogram results

Posts.Content: Thanks for all your replies. I've had a few tears as although prepared for further surgery, it has knocked me back a few paces and made me anxious. I've calmed down as I've got a grip of it. Thankfully I recovered from the first surgery I had on 2nd December pretty quickly and the dressing is already off. Dreamthief - they took 3 nodes and one tested positive. They have mentioned removing Axillary Nodes at 2nd surgery but didn't mention how many. I've been given the low down on lymphoma and prevention.
Posts.Title: Further surgery after Sentinel Node Biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly you have every right to have a moan as we have all been through and some are still going through a traumatic experience. I look back and can't believe that after my second chemo in August 2014 I stood in the kitchen and let my husband shave off my hair! I had already chosen a selection of wigs from our local Cancer Support Unit but was in total denial that I would lose my hair.  Somehow I just got on with it and found a wig that suited me and it served me throughout. Looking at the positives I was able to get ready for work much quicker without all that washing, blow drying and straightening! My hair started to grow back at the beginning of last year albeit grey and curly!  In the end I couldn't keep it under my wig so went to see a local hairdresser who has also had chemo. She was shocked when I first removed my wig but was brilliant and guided me re colouring etc. Like you I was desperate for my fringe to grow down as that seemed to take the longest but I have had two hair cuts since.  Hang on in there ... your hair will be back before you know it.  Our hair is part of our identity and it is understandably difficult when we have no control over losing it - I have just read that Victoria Derbyshire, the journalist is finding losing her hair the hardest part of her treatment.  The main thing is you are here and your family and friends will love you with or without hair.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: I'm not 'me'

Posts.Content: Hi Ann I can echo Maggie's post completely  ... I have been through the same physically and mentally, the only difference is I was diagnosed at the end of May last year.  If it wasn't for the fatigue, which sometimes feels worse some days than when I was going through treatment plus the joint aches, I could believe it has all been a bad dream! I described to those on a course I attended as having the sensation of stepping outside of myself during chemo, surgery and radiotherapy - like it was happening to someone else.  I think maybe psychologically it's a way of coping.  I expected to feel ecstatic once I was finished treatment but just feel quite numb when I think of all I've been through this past year. Like Maggie I am always on the go and have a full diary plus work in the mornings.  Today has caught up with me and I am very lethargic with no motivation to do anything. My best advice ... take one step at a time and cross bridges as you get to them.  Keep moving forward and be kind to yourself. Denise xx
Posts.Title: New to all this!

Posts.Content: Hi all - I together with my two daughters have entered Race For Life on 7th June and so far have raised over £1k!  It's great to feel I am giving something back.  I plan to wear pink leggings, pink tutu, pink wig plus my Race For Life T shirt with "Team Salmon" on the back.  My story is on www.justgiving.com/denisesalmon With my achy joints will be doing a fast walk rather than a race but I will do it!  Wish me luck.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Race for Life

Posts.Content: I went this afternoon for the results following my Lumpectomy and Sentinel Node Biopsy. Unfortunately I have to have further surgery on 23rd December to remove a further "slither" of tissue and some lymph nodes. Although prepared, I was disappointed. Has anybody else experienced this?
Posts.Title: Further surgery after Sentinel Node Biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Littlesusie Thanks for your response.  I feel better today ... think I was having a super sensitive day yesterday! My family and friends have been hugely supportive but I just want them to go about their lives as they usually would.  For instance, my daughter came home early yesterday from spending the day with her boyfriend to be with me.  This was a lovely gesture but I don't want to feel I am impacting on her life in this way.  I love my friends and family and really value their support.  I suppose if people did ask after me I would feel sad about this too.  It's a strange situation ... you want people to care but not let cancer take over your identity and be the sole focus. Love and hugs. Denise xx
Posts.Title: Fed up of cancer being the focus ...

Posts.Content: Hi Lorraine I am suffering with aching arms, shoulders and knees.  I've had 10 Herceptin injections so far but don't know whether it's this or the Letrazole tablets that are to blame.  I was taking my tablets in the morning but have started taking them in the evening recently which is supposed to help with sleep disturbance.  I was asked prior to my surgery whether I could be pregnant - like you I am 55.  The nurse told me they have to check all women between the ages of 12 - 55 for pregnancy.  She also said that one lady who was in for surgery did actually find out she was pregnant at that time!   My husband had suffered a heart attack a couple of days before I went in for surgery and I think this might have given him another one!  We were both in hospital on 23rd December as he was admitted while I was in having surgery ... talk about doing things together - thankfully we are both now on the mend.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Are any of you having Herceptin injections?

Posts.Content: Hi Petrina ... I really feel for you and hope that hope the new lump is nothing serious and maybe the result of previous treatment.   Yes I have always worn my wig or a scarf indoors with family around.  It is only now that my hair is slowly coming back (albeit it fifty shades of grey) that I sometimes take my wig off but only indoors.  I must admit one thing I have had to get my head around once I get through the treatment is the fact that it could come back!  I am determined I will not let the fear of cancer control my life though and will take things as they come ... probably easier said than done!  Thinking of you and sending positive thoughts xx
Posts.Title: Fed up of cancer being the focus ...

Posts.Content: Thanks for your responses ... it's good to know Im not on my own and going crazy with this.  We have always planned to move away to the Isle of Wight when we retire and this has made me want to do so more than ever!  It would be lovely to have normality back ... something I used to take for granted!  People who don't understand a thing about breast cancer can say things that are inappropriate, looking at you with pity in their eyes and speaking in hushed tones which doesn't help!
Posts.Title: Fed up of cancer being the focus ...

Posts.Content: Hi Katee Yes I too feel "normal" most days and I too have put on weight ... eek!  I had to weigh mysefl this morning to complete a questionnaire for a bone density scan I am having this afternoon (to monitor any effects of Letrazole tablets) and got a shock!  I weigh more than I did when I was full term with my first pregnancy albeit that was many years ago!  Looking on the bright side, it's better than losing weight as we need our strength to get through this.  I will worry about losing the weight and getting fit once treatment is over. Take care. Denise x
Posts.Title: Fed up of cancer being the focus ...

Posts.Content: Hi Ali I can identify with the lack of "me" time prior to diagnosis and the need to seriously reassess things. I was working part-time and also doing voluntary work for a family charity.  I was regularly working extra unpaid hours in my job and was always willing to be flexible and fill in when others wouldn't.  I even covered for someone the day after my diagnosis!  In years past I worked  while raising a family with little time to spare and have always been used to tearing around and looking after others.  This has been a wake up call - now is the time to put myself first.  We all never thought this would happen to us but here we are. Sending love and positive thoughts. Denise xx
Posts.Title: Fed up of cancer being the focus ...

Posts.Content: Thanks Nannymary - diverting the conversation sounds a brilliant coping mechanism which I will adopt.  I feel positive 90% of the time but the odd careless comment can bring me down.  I need to remember that many of these people gave little or no knowledge of the Breast cancer journey as I myself did not this time last year.  Some people feel they need to say something but it's not always the most appropriate thing and I can't bear that pitying look some people give you as though you are dying.  I know the big C word still evokes terror as it did in me when I was first diagnosed.  I just want to get on with my life now and not live in fear.  I event went through a phase of wanting to move away when we retire where no-one knows what I've been through so I can be treated "normal" again! Denise xx
Posts.Title: Mixed day yesterday ....

Posts.Content: Started back to work yesterday on a phase back basis and feeling good.  I only work part-time so although I still have radiotherapy to do agreed with Occupational Health to give it a go.  I am starting a new role in a Family Centre in a different location following a restructure at the end of last year. I was introduced to the new team  who are very friendly.  My Line Manager  then had a return to work catch up chat during which she told me there are several people in the team with family/friends who are going through cancer treatment with a less positive outlook.  I didn't know how to feel about that - am I not to talk to anyone about my treatment and act like it never happened?  I feel a bit like the "elephant in the room" especially as I do not know the individuals involved. Went for my Herceptin injection in the afternoon which was all fine but felt really tired.  In the evening we went to a retirement do for a member of the fire service as my husband was in the service for 31 years. The fireman retiring and his wife are a lovely couple who we have known for many years but have not seen in a long while.  When we arrived she greeted us then with a simpering look on her face said she had only just heard about what I had gone through and was sorry to hear it.  She then went on to tell me that her friend got the all clear then got it in the other breast and got the all clear then got it in her spine and died within three months!  Evening ruined - totally changed my mood.  Fortunately at the end of the evening I was talking to another wife of one ex fireman who went through all treatment and is now five years clear ... helped raise my mood again.  Love to you all going through this - glad we have each other. Denise xx
Posts.Title: Mixed day yesterday ....

Posts.Content: Hi Monika - yes I realise it can go both ways.  I waited until I'd had my second chemo before I allowed imy diagnosis to become widely known.  I received a lot of support but then became frustrated at it being the focus of any conversation anyone had with me!  However I do recall in the early days after diagnosis being frustrated that my daughter and her boyfriend appeared more concerned about his mum's marriage break up.  I know now I was being totally irrational  I suppose it's just getting the balance right.  My husband had a heart attack just before Christmas and was in hospital the same day as I was having my second surgery!  He has kept this fairly quiet so the focus has remained on me. Denise xx
Posts.Title: Mixed day yesterday ....

Posts.Content: I don't know if anyone feels like I do in this but I am worn down by being the focus of conversation because of cancer. Don't get me wrong I appreciate people's concern but it would be so nice to be able to meet friends, neighbours or colleagues without cancer being the main conversation point. I was really annoyed with my husband for telling local dog walkers about my diagnosis as sometimes it's nice to go for a walk and feel "normal". Maybe I'm just being over sensitive. Sorry to moan xx
Posts.Title: Fed up of cancer being the focus ...

Posts.Content: Funnily enough I was only saying to my husband yesterday that I plan to wear the stockings I was given in hospital when we fly in July.  I wasn't sure how long you needed to wear them before or after so any advice is welcome.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Flight stockings

Posts.Content: Funnily enough I was only saying to my husband yesterday that I plan to wear the stockings I was given in hospital when we fly in July.  I wasn't sure how long you needed to wear them before or after so any advice is welcome.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Flight stockings

Posts.Content: Hi Grogg I broke my fifth metatarsal in October  and was in a boot for a few weeks.  I had only finished radiotherapy a couple of months before but my foot healed really quickly - hope yours does too.  Denise
Posts.Title: Leg in plaster

Posts.Content: Hi Sandy I can certainly identify with how your feeling.  I was diagnosed at the end of May, had 7 sessions of chemo followed by a lumpectomy then axillary node removal.  I go through phases of feeling really well and on top of things and then there are times I'm down and just want to cry and cry.  I think it's good to let it all out and then get yourself back on track. The diagnosis itself is devastating and its hard when everything around you seems to be carrying on as normal but then I feel selfish as there are people going through worse. My husband, family and friends have been amazing in their support and I know not everyone in my situation has this.  I'm just recovering from second surgery which is taking a little longer but I will get there.  It's a long journey with highs and lows along the way but each day us a step nearer in recovery. Keep strong and positive.  Wishing you love and hugs (((xxx))) Denise
Posts.Title: How should i be feeling??????

Posts.Content: Just phoned for the result of my first mammogram post treatment and was given the fabulous news of ALL CLEAR.  I can't believe it, feel so blessed and humbled. Thought I would share my positive news with you all.
Posts.Title: Result of first mammogram today ...

Posts.Content: Hi Monika123 - I was told you usually get the results at your next Consultant or Oncologist appointment.  I had seen the Oncologist only the day before and the Consultant only a couple of weeks before so expected a letter.   I was working on the theory "No news is good news" but today was the 13th working day since I had my mammogram so I decided to ring the Consultant's secretary.   If I am honest I was putting this off!  If it's after 10 working days since your mammogram you should ring for the results.   Hope you get the good news I did.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Result of first mammogram today ...

Posts.Content: Hi Bev 47 if it's been over 10 working days since your mammogram phone for results.   I waited 13 days but I'm sure they would have contacted you by now if there was a problem. Let us know but all fingers crossed for you. Denise xx
Posts.Title: Result of first mammogram today ...

Posts.Content: Hi I finished Herceptin injections last September following chemo, lumpectomy and radiotherapy.  I am now on Letrazole which I have been taking for 14 months.  I work part time and try to get on with life but am frustrated that often I still need a doze in the afternoon and sometimes spend the evening snoozing on the sofa!  This evening we were going to go out for a meal but as Tuesday is my longer working day I persuaded hubby we should stay home ... good job as I have slept most of the evening! At times I also get a racing heartbeat even when I'm resting and my blood pressure has sometimes been high when tested.  I think the Letrazole has a lot to do with all this.  I had a blood test recently which showed my iron levels were low and alkaline phosphatase was raised.  GP sent a copy of the results to my oncologist and Breast Cancer Nurse phoned me today to reassure me that oncologist has seen results and is not unduly concerned as these changes in blood are common following chemo. It might be worth you having a blood test though just to check your levels. Denise xx
Posts.Title: Frustrated lack of energy

Posts.Content: Hi all - I would definitely recommend the course.  It teaches strategies and techniques for coping post treatment as well as nutritional advice.  I have also met four other ladies who have had Breast Cancer which has been a great support and we intend to continue meeting up after the course ends.   I attend the course at The Olive Tree, the cancer support unit attached to our local hospital.  I will enquire when I go on Wednesday as to availability in other locations and feedback.  Denise
Posts.Title: A few tips from my Cancer Survivorship Course

Posts.Content: Hi Judith I live in Horsham and attend the course at The Olive Tree which is the Cancer support unit attached to Crawley Hospital.  I know they repeat the course every few months.  I will ask the tutor tomorrow evening about availability in other locations and let you know. Denise xx
Posts.Title: A few tips from my Cancer Survivorship Course

Posts.Content: Hi chris47 you can attend the course while you are still having treatment as I was.  The aim is to teach you strategies and stress relieving techniques for coping post treatment. It also offers nutrition advice to boost your immune system to help prevent recurrence.  It also provides an opportunity to meet with people who have been through or who are going through Cancer treatment and share experiences which can be very supportive.   Denise xx
Posts.Title: A few tips from my Cancer Survivorship Course

Posts.Content: Well today is our 29th wedding anniversary - not bad especially as it's second time for both of us!  While I was in hospital having my second surgery on 23rd December 2014, I woke up in recovery to find my husband had been admitted as he had suffered a heart attack!  We were both kept in - I came home Christmas Eve, he came home Christmas morning and thanks to being well prepared and our amazing children, Christmas Day went on as usual! We are both grateful to be here celebrating this anniversary and hope to have many more years to come. Hope you are all doing well too.
Posts.Title: Celebration today ...

Posts.Content: Hi all I asked my tutor this evening and, unfortunately, the Cancer Survivorship Programme is only run in the South East at the moment.  He suggested asking at your local cancer support unit as there may be similar courses on offer in different areas.  The website for CSP which has some good information on is www.cancersurvivorshipprogramme.co.uk  Some recipes can be found on the Resources tab. We tried some cookies this evening made from anti cancer ingredients - they were a bit like flapjack and were delicious.  Recipes can be found under the Resources tab on the CSP website - see link above.  We also tried a drink made from 1/4 teaspoon of each ginger, turmeric, cinnamon and cloves and half a teaspoon of raw honey.  It was a bit like a chai latte and has huge anti cancer properties.  We were also told to use rapeseed oil to cook rather then olive oil to ensure the Omega 3 good oils are in our diet rather than Omega 6 oils which are bad.  It is all very interesting and I know we need to take all things in moderation but anything that is going to help my body and immune system keep healthy is worth the effort.   Denise xx
Posts.Title: A few tips from my Cancer Survivorship Course

Posts.Content: Hi all - just a few things I wanted to pass on that I have picked up so far from the course I am attending. Firstly, stress reduction is essential to aid recovery and help reduce risk of recurrence.  We have been learning mindfulness, breathing and imaging techniques to help reduce stress at times such as scans / check ups.  Exercise has also been proven without doubt to be beneficial.  This doesn't have to be gym exercise but can be walking for 30 mins 3-4 times a week. We have also been learning about anti cancer foods.  I was already aware of the benefits of wheatgrass and have started taking the powdered form in a drink regularly.  Last week we were told about Matcha which is apparently off the scale in anti cancer properties.  It can be bought from teapigs  http://www.teapigs.co.uk/tea/shop_by_category/matcha_shop#matchatab-intro. I don't know about you but if I think it can help us stay healthy and fight cancer, despite it not tasting that great, I am willing to give it a go!  Garlic is also excellent in preventing cancer cells mutating.  A clove a day is recommended. This week our tutor is bringing some home baked cookies that apparently taste delicious but are full of things that are good for us.  I will feedback later in the week. Love and hugs. Denise xx
Posts.Title: A few tips from my Cancer Survivorship Course

Posts.Content: Hi Liz thanks for adding that information.  It's good to know the courses are available further afield.   The one I am attending is 8 weeks but I am sure is similar in what it delivers.  Our tutor explained how although treatment in the UK is excellent, many people struggle with fears and adjusting to the new "normal" once treatment ends so this course aims to teach techniques for dealing with this.  It is session 7 this week and we have all agreed we will miss it so plan to continue to meet up both socially and to practice what we have learnt.  On average the course has up to 10 attendees but this time there are only 5 of us and all have had breast cancer so we have formed a close group.  I hope you find your course beneficial too - I would be interested to read feedback.   Denise xx
Posts.Title: A few tips from my Cancer Survivorship Course

Posts.Content: Thanks Peepee - that's given me the boost I needed. Feel so emotional today yet I've been so positive up to now. I'm sure a lot of it is in the mind as I went into work to touch base yesterday morning and was feeling really up right through till I received the news in the afternoon when my mood changed which also affected me physically. I just want to get 2nd op done now so I can feel Im on the road to recovery. I will heed your advice to keep moving forward with positivity. xx
Posts.Title: Cried all morning but getting back on track ....

Posts.Content: Morning all - after the euphoria of being told clear margins had been received following my 2nd op, I have hit a phase of feeling down worrying about the future.  My husband who has been a rock throughout is getting tired of me being negative as he heard the Consultant say that effectively the cancer was gone.  I had one out of 10 lymph nodes affected but can't help stressing about this.  I had vowed I was not going to let the fear of cancer returning rule my life and planned to live every day.  I even said I was not afraid of it anymore then out if the blue this low mood hit.  I have just completed my first of three weeks of daily radiotherapy and am in daily Letrazole and three weekly Herceptin injections. I have just started reading "The Cancer Survivor's Companion" by Dr Frances Goodhart and Lucy Atkins.  It has really good reviews and received a Book Award in 2012.  Although I have only just started it, I can identify with loads of what I have read so far and realise how "normal" what I am experiencing is.  I bought it off EBay and would recommend it.  I am also attending a "Cancer Survivorship Programme" at The Olive Tree, the cancer support unit attached to our local hospital.  This teaches strategies and techniques for coping post cancer treatment as well as nutrition advice. I seemed to be fine during the middle part of treatment and didn't expect to feel like this now as I am almost through it!  However, as I said it seems it is normal and many people feel this way.   Sending best wishes and a hug to you all. Denise xx
Posts.Title: Book recommendation for those post treatment ...

Posts.Content: Hi Dreamthief - yes The Olive Tree have provided amazing support since my diagnosis from providing my wig, yoga and massage as well as weekly drop in sessions.  My oncologist has referred me for acupuncture with them to help with joint pain.  I actually applied for an Admin job with them recently and was offered it!  However, after consideration I decided to stay in my current job for now. I do intend offering to do a few hours a week voluntary work for them.  Denise x
Posts.Title: Book recommendation for those post treatment ...

Posts.Content: After the news yesterday that I need further surgery to remove a "slither" of tissue left behind and also axillary lymph node clearance, I woke very down this morning. I have been so strong and positive throughout my chemo treatment but once I started cryingI couldn't stop. it was good to get it out. I was prepared for further surgery but feel that I have gone back a few paces. I have already picked up this afternoon and I recovered quickly from my first surgeryon 2nd December so onward and upwards.
Posts.Title: Cried all morning but getting back on track ....

Posts.Content: Thank you for your responses - you are all so lovely and it's great to know I am not alone in this.  Thanks Sue for the suggested support links - will take a look.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Book recommendation for those post treatment ...

Posts.Content: Hi Weeble it is perfectly natural to act and feel the way you did.  At my second op follow up I was told they had achieved clear margins and the cancer was gone.  I just sat there as numb as when I was first diagnosed.  It was after my last of 15 sessions of radiotherapy that I cried on the way home.  I think it's because we set ourselves milestones on this journey and it's when we reach them we reflect on what we have been through!  After diagnosis you are on a roller coaster of appointments and treatments and when its all done you think you will feel ecstatic yet can feel bewildered.  The 8 week Cancer Survivorship Programme I attended focused on this very thing, strategies and techniques for coping post treatment as there does not seem to be enough consideration given to the emotional effect of cancer.  I hope you soon feel stronger, just remember how well you have done to get this far. Sending hugs of reassurance - we are all on this journey together  ((xx)) Denise
Posts.Title: Good news!!

Posts.Content: Best wishes for today Stoatie.  I definitely felt better once treatment had started knowing chemo was in my body attacking the imposter!  Keep positive - cross bridges when you get to them and deal with side effects if and when you get them.  Each step is one nearer to the end of treatment. It doesn't seem five minutes since I was on the starting blocks but 7 chemos and 2 ops later now onto radiotherapy. Sending big hugs ((xx)) Denise xx
Posts.Title: Starting FEC T today

Posts.Content: Hi Lins - as Weeble said you could be over compensating by using your other arm for more things.  I found the same with my left hand and realised it was because I was naturally doing more with my left hand than before.  Denise x
Posts.Title: UNDERARM PAIN

Posts.Title: Help ......

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca I was diagnosed at the end of May - the day after my daughter's 21st birthday celebrations.  I was so convinced it would be nothing so was devastated at the cancer diagnosis.  I had 7 sessions of chemo first and had a lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy on 2nd December.  The operation was pretty straightforward and the procedure should be fully explained to you beforehand.  You should also get to speak to the Macmillan nurse who was assigned to you who will be able to answer any questions you may have prior to the op.  Recovery has been fairly swift with minimal pain.  You will be given daily exercises to do to help recovery.  Unfortunately my post op results showed a slither of remaining tissue that needs to be removed plus some further lymph nodes so I am booked in for a second op on Tuesday, the same day as your lumpectomy. It is overwhelming at first when following the shock of diagnosis you are bombarded with literature - there is so much to take in.  As you start to accept the diagnosis, as hard as it is, and have a treatment plan in place, you will feel strong enough to read more and ask for further information if you need it.  There is plenty of support from your Macmillan nurse or on this site where people who have undergone or who are going through similar treatment can share experiences. It is a long journey but take things one step at a time and cross bridges as you get to them.  Stay strong and try to keep positive as there is lots of treatment available.  Hope all goes well with the lumpectomy - I will be thinking of you as I prepare for my second op! Love and hugs. Denise x
Posts.Title: The unknown

Posts.Content: Hi shaz15 sorry to have to welcome you to this group - not one any of us want to join but definitely the best for friendship, support and encouragement so you are in the right place!  I can honestly say the waiting for my biopsy results last June and then the treatment plan were the most stressful times - I think I was counting the hours!   Easier said than done but please try not to worry as once you have your treatment plan in place and know what you are dealing with you will feel more in control of things. Also once treatment starts you will be surprised how quickly the weeks and months pass until before you know it you are crossing the finishing line.  It can all seem overwhelming but my advice is to take things one step at a time and cross bridges as you get to them. There are lots of possible treatment side effects but we are all different and remember it doesn't mean you will get them.There is always someone to share experiences with on here and to gain support and reassurance including George who oversees the sight and is a font of knowledge when it comes to breast cancer.  Do you know the type or stage of your diagnosis yet?  Sending reassuring hugs (( xx)) - stay strong, you can do this!  Denise xx

Posts.Title: Mammograms after treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Neet - I know it can seem overwhelming - I cried when I saw my treatment plan and thought I couldn't do it.  My advice is just take it one step at a time and cross bridges when you get to them - don't stress about what is to come.  This worked for me and kept things under control.  They have to explain all the side effects to you as a matter of protocol but it doesn't mean you are going to get them. If you do get any there are things to help you plus loads of support and advice on this site.  Each day is a day nearer to recovery.  I had 7 sessions of chemo, two surgeries and am now halfway through 15 sessions of radiotherapy. I went to see a friend yesterday who was at the end of her treatment when I started mine and we agreed how quickly the time has gone.  You can do this! Sending hugs ((xx)) Denise
Posts.Title: Pre chemo check

Posts.Content: Hi JJsailor I can totally relate to your post as I know will many others.  Following the initial devastation of diagnosis I strode through all my treatment sessions, ticking them off as I went.  It was tough at times but I ploughed on undeterred.  Then .... after the initial euphoria of being told there was NED I plunged into waves of anxiety, depression and mood swings ... horrendous. I am currently having counselling through my local Cancer Support Unit which I am finding helpful.  It's good to be able to say exactly what's in your head and working out ways to deal with it.  My husband and family were hugely supportive throughout treatment but you can almost hear them sigh whenever cancer creeps into the conversation now I am through it.  It's like they are waiting for me to bring it up. They have moved on from what was a traumatic event for everyone and expect me to do the same ... not so easy.  What you are feeling is perfectly normal - it's almost like post traumatic stress.  I'm glad you are going to speak to your BCN - it was mine who suggested the counselling and set the ball rolling by referring me. Denise xx

Posts.Title: Is it just me ...

Posts.Content: Hi I am new to the group. I was diagnosed with breast cancer at the end of May. The feelings of devastation following the initial diagnosis and anxiety waiting for a biopsy and the result were extremely hard to deal with. Your mind takes you to all weird and wonderful places! Once my treatment plan was in place I felt more in control. I am having neo adjuvant chemo prior to a lumpectomy. I have just had my 4th session of EC chemo and will start my first session of Docetaxel followed by my first Herceptin end Sept. Apart from hair loss, nausea and sleep disturbance I have been fairly ok so consider myself fortunate. I am very apprehensive about the side effects of the Docetaxel and any reactions on the first session. I know I will need to just go with it and manage side effects as they present. Surgery will follow and possibly radiotherapy. It's a long journey with good days, bad days emotionally - bit of a roller coaster but overall keeping strong and positive. I would like to hear from anyone who has had the same treatment plan. Sorry about my user name - tried loads more before this but they had been taken so in desperation ha ha. Look forward to chatting later - off to work today. Denise

Posts.Title: Next stage chemo ... feeling nervous

Posts.Content: Hi Lorylinge I was really concerned about the firmness around the site of my lumpectomy. I did mention it to the Consultant at my follow up and he didn't seem too concerned but as I was due for my first mammogram he booked it to reassure me.  This all came back clear for which I am extremely thankful. I researched the subject and it seems common for there to be hardening of the tissue surrounding the site of the operation. It's recommended that you use E45 or similar on the area but it can take some time fir the tissue to return to normal.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: A question for my friends

Posts.Content: Hi Scribblinglady - it's always good to be prepared for a second surgery as that way if you don't need it that will be a bonus!  I was warned before my first surgery on 2nd December that I might need a second operation - apparently about 25% of ladies do.  Even so, I was quietly confident I wouldn't and was preparing to start back to work in January.  I had a lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy with one of three nodes removed showing cancer.  I was told  at my operation follow up on 12th December that I would need a second surgery to remove a "slither" of remaining tissue in order to get clear margins and also to have an axillary node dissection.  I was really upset as I felt my recovery had been knocked back. Fortunately my second surgery was promptly arranged on 23rd December when the remaining tissue and 7 nodes were removed all of which were clear.  I am now onto radiotherapy -10 down 5 to go!  Here's hoping you won't need a second surgery but fore-warned is fore-armed.  Wishing you all the best in your treatment and recovery.  Denise x
Posts.Title: They didn't say this before!

Posts.Content: Hi all - I am home alone this afternoon and had to vent my opinion.  I just came in from doing some gardening and was browsing through Facebook while having a cuppa.  Someone had put a video on where the person tells their story by holding up cards with words on.  It was a young mum who had gone through breast cancer treatment to then be told it had become secondary and incurable.  Whilst I have great empathy for her situation it depressed me.  As breast cancer patients we are all aware of the risks along the way but strive to stay as positive as possible and face things if and when they arise.   I think this is the only way we can get on with our lives.  All I am saying is that if I thought the video on Facebook was going to help her then I would be all for it but it just brought my mood down.  How do others feel about this?   I met a young mum on my Cancer Survivorship Course and she texted me late one evening as she was struggling and asked if she could come to see me the next evening.  As we are fairly new friends I felt privileged that she had turned to me for support.  She has two children, the youngest being only 2 years old and her Breast lump was originally dismissed as a milk duct.  Although she is on Herceptin and Tamoxifen for 10 years, her Oncologist wants her to have an additional injection (can't recall what the drug is called) every month possibly for life.  This is because she is pre menopausal.  This had knocked her back but we were able to chat and support each other and definitely plan meeting up again.  I do appreciate how it must be even more difficult to deal with when you are diagnosed so young.  Denise xx
Posts.Title: Is it just me ...

Posts.Content: Thank you ladies - I felt bad for putting this on as didn't want to seem heartless.  It's just that I can't see what purpose it serves.  Surely it's better to raise awareness but show some positive results for anyone facing it.  Whilst I feel extremely sad for the young woman involved I can't see why people other than her close family and friends need to read it.  My heart goes out to my 30 year old friend as she has young children.  Whilst trying to stay strong to support her I can't dwell on it too much as find it so emotional imagining myself being diagnosed when my children were that young.  At least mine have grown up although I hope and pray I have many more years with them yet.  Yes Julia I removed it from my news feed too after feeling compelled to watch it!  I am six months post treatment - we are living it so don't need to see things like this. Denise xx
Posts.Title: Is it just me ...

Posts.Content: Hi Lizane I have just read your post - shocking beyond words!  I'm almost in tears imagining how you must have felt being given a terminal diagnosis.  I am delighted for your good news but feel you should seriously take action against the Registrar - it is totally unacceptable and inexcusable.  The wife of someone I work with was also diagnosed by a Registrar who, after referring to a book, told her she had terminal lung and bowel cancer.  That was in 2008 when she was 34 and just after she had given birth to her third child.  As you can imagine it was devastating news.  Well she is still here doing really well and is now having treatment to remove the tumours which she had been told were inoperable! She is an absolute inspiration. Her Oncologist has admitted the Registrar misdiagnosed her and subsequently received a disciplinary at the least.  Also When my daughter's fiancé's dad had skin cancer he was told to put his affairs in order as he had about six weeks to live.  He got a second opinion, cancer was removed and that was 10 years ago!  Do these people realise what they are doing to a person's mental state?  How would they feel being given that diagnosis? To be given a terminal diagnosis is bad enough to come to terms with but to be given it in error is beyond comprehension in my mind.  Sending you hugs and best wishes for your recovery going forward. Denise xx
Posts.Title: Told I was misdiagnosed and it's NOT bone secondaries, it's Avascular...

Posts.Content: Hi Ali I am awake at this unearthly hour because I crashed out for two hours earlier!  Sorry to hear your news.  I was warned before my first surgery that sometimes you have to have a second op depending on what they find.  Even so, I was so sure I wouldn't. My scar had started to heal nicely, I had been that very morning on a tour with my Manager to see where my new job would be - there had been a restructure while I was off recovering from my first surgery.  I was feeling so positive and good and then in the afternoon when I went for my post op appointment was told a scond surgery was needed to remove a "slither" of remaining tissue in order to get clear margins.  I held it together but inside was devastated.  I felt it was a real knock back to getting back to some sort of normality.  I cried all the next morning and had to let  my Manager know that I would not be returning to work as I thought.   But hey here I am four months down the line, back to work and getting on with it.  I admit it hasn't been easy at times but I did it and so can you!  Sending hugs of encouragement ((xx)) Denise

Posts.Content: Hi all - I don't know about you but sometimes when I am feeling unsure and nervous it does me good to read stories of cancer survivors.  When looking for books or online testimonies of survivors I have noticed that America is way ahead in collating and publishing these.  I know many people probably just want to get on with their lives and try to put it behind them - my Macmillan nurse told me at the beginning of my treatment that there are far more breast cancer survivors out there than people realise.  It would just be nice to hear UK survival stories more often. What does anyone else think? Denise xx
